Time is not on our side when it comes to #climatechange. Now that it's 2023, we're another year closer to 2050 & our goal to achieve net-zero emissions economy-wide.

We must implement. Our environment will continue to be one of my top focuses in the #118thCongress.

Thank you for counting down with me as we look back on legislation that will shape this nation for decades.
 
The future is bright, and I'm proud to be one of Maryland's voices in the new year, in a new Congress.
In Nov. 2021, we changed this narrative by enacting a historic law that creates jobs, invests in infrastructure, and honors this country's blueprint.

1. Bipartisan Infrastructure Law: We're ending the thread with another heavy-hitter. For years, our aging infrastructure has held back progress toward thriving, resilient, and connected communities for all.

Maryland State Police will be increasing patrols to watch for drunk drivers. Please don’t drink and drive. Pick a designated driver, take Metro or use a taxi or car-share service.
 
For @wmata users, rides are free after 8 p.m.
https://t.co/qkiw8M4AlO

Two icons lost. #Pelé and #BarbaraWalters. They showed us all what hard work and dedication means, while blazing a trail for all who came after. Their legacies reach far beyond #futball and broadcasting. #changemakers #beautifulgame https://t.co/SbPdaPMfcl

2. #InflationReductionAct: This bold legislation delivers a range of benefits, including one of the country's most urgent costs: #climatechange. 

We devoted $369B to efforts that will promote electric vehicles, slash methane pollution & provide clean energy tax credits.

3. Every second counts in a crisis. This year, we saw the launch of 988, the new three digit lifeline transforming our crisis care system. The Bipartisan Safer Communities Act and the #omnibus continues to invest in the new lifeline.

Congrats @LeaderHoyer on a legacy of leadership. My friend, you have been a proud voice for Maryland and our nation. 

I can't wait to see what's next.
https://t.co/mXm2JgO887

4. The Emmett Till Lynching Act: In 1955, 14-year-old Emmett Till was murdered by a racist mob in Mississippi. 

Emmett loved baseball, fishing and riding bikes. His life mattered. 

We passed legislation that makes lynching a federal crime. https://t.co/24xagG3AjK

I discussed this issue in one of my recent letters to Marylanders on the critical need to publicly stand up to antisemitism, which you can read in full, here: 
https://t.co/GKrs6jkce3 https://t.co/xUaDUZKK6f

For those interested, here is a longer version of the video referencing hate speech from our recent hearing.

Hate speech is protected under the #FirstAmendment, unless it incites violence. #context https://t.co/A0J1sNzYUH

Marylanders, if you've been affected by flight cancellations and are making alternative plans to get home, keep your receipts and document everything.

Thank you to the staff at @BWI_Airport who have been working long hours trying to sort this out.

Wishing nothing but the best for my friend and #TeamMaryland member, @RepRaskin. We are behind you 100 percent, always. 

https://t.co/Y1Ub8j4dZQ

For those struggling with a mental illness or finding "cheer" this holiday season, I see you, and you're not alone. 
 
If you feel unsafe or need to talk, please call the crisis line at #988.

Our first amendment is one of the defining jewels of this country. ✅

It is NOT a free pass to spew violent rhetoric. 🚫 https://t.co/4IvCeVq10S

5. The Bipartisan Safer Communities Act: After decades of a grid-lock on gun safety, we passed historic legislation that increases accountability, better protects victims of domestic violence & elevates mental health services. 

We have a long road ahead, but this set the tone.

I will try again in the 118th Congress to have enacted a Senate Resolution declaring that Russians in Ukraine are committing genocide.

https://t.co/gMOd0KlaAp

One of the five major categories of acts that constitute genocide is “forcibly transferring children of that group to another group.” Which is what #Russia is doing in #Ukraine.

https://t.co/ar3pXARDuH

Genocide is an internationally recognized crime where acts are committed with the intent to destroy - in whole or in part - a national, ethnic, racial, or religious group, according to the @HolocaustMuseum.
https://t.co/c3AGK5mucE

6. The Respect for Marriage Act: When Roe v. Wade was shamefully overturned by SCOTUS, many #LGBTQ people were fearful that their marriages could be the next target.

Last month, we protected same-sex and interracial marriage, declaring that love wins, always.

Tonight is the 8th and final day of #Hanukkah or Zose Hanukkah.

With antisemitic acts on the rise, I've never been prouder of my Jewish heritage and people. I know the hatred is draining, but our voices #ShineALight in the dark. https://t.co/XVcs8wWbQk

7. Telehealth: We've learned so much in the past few years about the importance of remote health care options.
 
We were able to pass multiple bills that helped expand telehealth in both Medicare and Medicaid -- further extended telehealth flexibilities in the #omnibus.

8. SBIR & STTR Reauthorization Act: We reauthorized SBIR & STTR programs through Sept. 2025, which promote ingenuity, technology & research that help #smallbiz + the economy grow.
 
The DOD found that between 1995-2018, these programs returned $22 for every $1 awarded. 💼

9. Under @POTUS’s leadership + investments from the American Rescue Plan, millions of Americans have been vaccinated against COVID-19. 

We continue to benefit from advancements in efforts to combat the pandemic, such as the updated bivalent booster shot. 💉

#Funded.

The #Omnibus passed the Senate this afternoon and with it, we established our goals, intentions and hopes for this country's future. 

This Congress was productive and ambitious. No one gets every item on their wish list, but this bill is compassionate and fair.

10. The Chips and Science Act: This legislation created more than 600,000 American manufacturing jobs, increased semiconductor research to keep the U.S. competitive in the field and spurred private companies to invest more than $44 billion in memory chip manufacturing. 💵

A new year and Congress will soon be here, and just like the ball drop at midnight, I thought I'd do a countdown myself. 

For each day until Jan. 1, I'll be highlighting some of our greatest achievements in the #117thCongress.

(P.S. No particular order. I don't do favorites.)

Honored to escort President Zelenskyy this evening for his address to Congress. 

We stand with the Ukrainian people. 🇺🇦 https://t.co/I7KVBn1bDf

Thank you, @POTUS, for your continued efforts to address antisemitism. 

This issue demands a "whole-of-society" approach. 
https://t.co/ocnaip0xWc

There's no doubt that antisemitism is gaining steam in this country.

The @ADL tells us there was a 61 percent increase in antisemitic acts from 2020-2021.

Thank you to my colleagues for supporting more Holocaust education in our schools. https://t.co/on0Vg6uA17

Only one legacy worth honoring. 

Proud to join @LeaderHoyer and @SpeakerPelosi today as she prepares our bill for the signature of @POTUS.

Two men. Both Marylanders. Both SCOTUS Justices. But Justice Roger Brooke Taney authored 1 of the worst decisions in SCOTUS history, perpetuating the myth that Blacks were inferior & couldn’t be citizens, while Justice Thurgood Marshall was a beacon of hope for racial equality. https://t.co/8naa6JDzRW

This usually festive time feels hollow this year due to Iranian authorities' despicable actions. 

Still, the brave protesters who have stood up are still bringing that light.

I stand with the Iranian people. Even on the longest, darkest night, light overcomes. #IranProtests

For months, peaceful Iranian protesters have been a beacon of light despite mounting human rights violations by the regime.

Tonight is the Winter Solstice - Shab-e Yalda, a traditional Persian celebration of the longest night giving way to light.

The Saver's Match will provide lower and middle-income Americans with a 50% matching contribution of up to $2,000 in retirement savings annually deposited directly into an IRA or retirement plan.

Hardworking Americans deserve to retire with dignity and financial security.

Retirement has been one of my focal issues from the moment I set foot in Congress. 

Included in the #OmnibusBill is Secure 2.0, which encompasses much of my bill with @senrobportman. It contains over 40 of our provisions, including the Saver's Match.
The omnibus also includes the bipartisan effort to reform the Electoral Count Act of 1887. This became necessary after the violent and illegitimate events of Jan. 6. https://t.co/m6zbZgkWxE

Fingerprints of this Congress' hard work are weaved throughout the omnibus, including:
🔹$92 million for Chesapeake Bay Program environmental restoration activities 
🔹$4.9 billion to address the opioid epidemic
🔹$8 billion (a 30% increase) for CCDBG child care grants

Twelve little lives. Twelve kids who should be getting ready for the holidays. Twelve families forever changed.
 
This isn't normal.
 
I'm proud that we passed the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, but our nation demands more.
https://t.co/bPsIeVZB3Y

I'm angry and tired. Another antisemitic act in Maryland -- this time on the Shabbat and right before the first night of Hanukkah.
 
This is why we will never back down. Our combined voices and light must be louder and stronger.
https://t.co/0r5aPSRvCI

Tonight is night 1 of Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights. 
It hasn't been an easy year for the Jewish community, but here we are still standing proudly. I am joining the @baltjc to #ShineALight on hate. 
Countering antisemitism is a public endeavor. Join us.
https://t.co/vqJtkRkw3D

#Sanctions are about accountability and using appropriate pressure to force a change for the better. 

This past week, 17 people were no longer deemed as threats to Zimbabwe’s democratic processes and institutions. Behavior can be changed, and we will recognize that.

The mission of @VOANews is to send real news to people in countries where free speech & independent journalism are not allowed. This work is part of America’s long-standing policy to inform audiences in countries that are not free.  Restore the accounts!

Elon Musk’s takedown of prominent journalists this week includes Steve Herman, of the Voice of America, as well as colleagues at CNN, NYT and WaPo.  This is not only wrong for the American press, it is bad for truth-telling around the world.

My friend Rep. John Lewis didn't waste a minute of his 80 years on earth. He was dedicated to making "good trouble," and this nation forever owes him for it.

Touched to see the @USPS honoring his legacy. 
https://t.co/AV1Koa8Yqv

Finally, I’m proud to say that we also passed the Water Resources Development Act, which supports supply chains, takes climate change seriously, and expands Army Corps assistance for disadvantaged communities. A huge win for MD and the country.

The NDAA also includes the #BurmaAct, which I was proud to introduce with @RepGregoryMeeks and @RepSteveChabot. This will hold the Burmese military accountable for its unjustifiable coup d’état. We must continue to stand with the people of Burma.
This includes a major investment to upgrade housing at Joint Base Andrews and expansion at the Bethesda Medical Center. Maryland will continue to play a crucial role in America’s national defense.

Last night we burned the midnight oil to pass critical investments to our national security and military. The #NDAA is a major bipartisan effort that will improve the quality of life for our service members and their families + allow for continued allyship to Ukraine.

The holidays aren’t a source of joy for everyone. For many people, this time of year can be incredibly isolating.

It should not take a horror like Sandy Hook or Uvalde to act. 

The Bipartisan Safer Communities Act was a monumental step this summer to address gun violence, but we need more action like universal background checks and bans on assault weapons.

We don't have to live this way.

Unfortunately, gun-related tragedies are happening all over the country, nearly every day. 
 
2022 is on track to have the second highest number of mass shootings in almost a decade.
 
More than 1,600 of the victims have been children.

These families have been through so much, yet here is Jennifer Hubbard, who lost her daughter Catherine, offering a solution that doesn't require legislation or a party majority. 

Compassion. Compassion, always.
https://t.co/HXiY4bOzcw

Remember their faces. Read about Emilie Parker making cards for her family or James "J" Mattioli's love for singing. 

Today hurts...and it should. May our heartache for the Sandy Hook families never fade. We must use that pain to fuel change. We owe them.
https://t.co/LCmAZZv2k8

Charlotte. Daniel. Rachel. Olivia. Josephine. Dylan. Dawn. Madeline. Catherine. Chase. Jesse. Ana. James. Grace. Ann Marie. Emilie. Jack. Noah. Caroline. Jessica. Avielle. Lauren. Mary. Victoria. Benjamin. Allison. https://t.co/jD2V6eN71J

Today, I hope those people take comfort knowing that their fight is our fight. #LoveWins.

Pop quiz, love…

A.) Will keep us together.

@POTUS, for taking the final step to protect same-sex and interracial marriage. #RespectForMarriageAct https://t.co/vdiUObHa7c

Inflation’s sharp edges are continuing to soften. The GDP is up nearly 3 percent from last quarter, and in the past month another 260,000 jobs have been created. 

There is more work ahead, but this is steady progress for a brighter economic future.

Today, I am chairing a Helsinki Commission on the rise of antisemitism partly fueled by people like rapper Ye who have used their enormous platforms to spread hateful rhetoric. 

Be a part of the conversation. The hearing will be livestreamed at 2 p.m.: https://t.co/7Fte7hgLtr

The work is never over. Two weeks ago, I convened a working group with high-level officials from across the government – including the White House, DOJ, DHS, State – and the non-profit sector who are actively engaged in countering antisemitism.

Very pleased that @POTUS is continuing to take on this issue. As a nation, we cannot allow antisemitism – or any other type of prejudice or intolerance – to be normalized. This sends a strong message from the top.

Last year, @RepGregoryMeeks @RepSteveChabot and I introduced the Burma Act, which would hold the Burmese military accountable through sanctions and provide humanitarian support to those in need.

We cannot be indifferent to the fate of Burma’s peoples.

It has almost been two years since the Burmese military's unjustifiable coup d’état and unfortunately, nothing has changed. 

The military continues to murder and unjustly arrest civilians. This is without a doubt a major humanitarian crisis.

A law: the 1969 Skamania County Ordinance no. 69¬01 making it illegal to kill Bigfoot in Washington State.

Not a law: the #EqualRightsAmendment that ensures gender equality for all.

Doesn't make much sense, does it? #ERANow

Millions of people have benefited from the medical advances and protections derived from Henrietta Lacks’ cells. I’m proud to help lead this effort with Senator @ChrisVanHollen to award the Congressional Gold Medal in recognition of the tremendous impact of her life and legacy. https://t.co/fcK9c9GIUd

Read more on the legacy of Henrietta Lacks here:
https://t.co/UcAY2UGmdf

In 2013, after 62 years of research and 62 years since Lacks’ death, Lacks’ family was granted some control over how her genome was being used.
 
Lacks’ story led to the rewriting of the rules around ethics in health care, including patient privacy and consent.

Doctors found that Lacks’ cells could thrive in a lab and were shipped around the world as the subject of 74k+ studies.
 
Her family did not know that her cells were alive or being used. The cells, called HeLa cells, laid the base for the multibillion-dollar biotech industry.

In 1951, Henrietta Lacks was a young mother who went to The Johns Hopkins Hospital, one of the few hospitals that would care for poor Black Americans, to be treated for cancer. While there, health providers removed her cells without her knowledge or consent.

That is why I have introduced legislation that would increase access to DXA testing for Medicare beneficiaries and preserve Medicare reimbursement rates for DXA testing.

Advocates believe that hospitals and physician practices acquired by hospitals have decreased the number of DXA tests performed on Medicare beneficiaries because they lose money on the low reimbursement rate.
Medicare covers preventive scans, called DXA, to detect osteoporosis for women, and covers limited DXA scans for men. An important test needed before prescribing medications to treat osteoporosis.

Osteoporosis is responsible for approximately 300,000 hip fracture hospitalizations and almost two million broken bones per year, yet nearly 80 percent of older Americans who suffer bone breaks are not tested or treated for the disease.

Q: I am fully vaccinated and just traveled to an area with low vaccination rates, does that mean I have to get tested for COVID?
A: Even if you’re fully vaccinated, you should still wear a mask during your trip and get tested after visiting an area with low vaccination rates.

Q: Do I need to wear a mask?
A: If you’re not vaccinated, the CDC recommends that you always wear a mask. If you’re fully vaccinated, the CDC recommends wearing masks indoors in COVID hotspots.

Q: Will my vaccine (J&J, Moderna, or Pfizer) protect against the delta variant?
A: All vaccines have shown protections against symptomatic diseases and hospitalizations against the delta variant. If you’re not vaccinated, the delta variant can potentially be life-threatening.

This legislation would take a meaningful step in undoing the harmful legacy of past infrastructure projects that have hindered the economic development and mobility of disadvantaged communities. It also recognizes the importance of community engagement and planning.

Rather than connecting their communities and expanding their opportunities, highway construction brought demolition, displacement, isolation, and exclusion. According to one estimate, the federal highway system, between 1956 and 1967, displaced more than 300,000 households.

Our national hwy system, built in the 1950s was a great achievement—a major public investment in infrastructure, transforming our country. We rely on it today. But for too many, especially communities of color, the construction of our hwys had traumatic and destructive impacts.

We are long overdue in taking hard look at how our federal #transportation policy can help address the challenge of inequity—the exclusion of disadvantaged communities and communities of color. Baltimore City is intimately familiar with this painful history of highway planning.

Starting now. My 1st hearing as chair of the @EPWCmte Transportation & Infrastructure Subcommittee. We're taking a look at "Equity in Transportation Infrastructure: Connecting Communities, Removing Barriers, and Repairing Networks across America.” Live: https://t.co/SI4u1oW3DK

Mike Miller was larger than life, a good friend, a good man who loved his family and community, and an incredible public servant who dedicated himself to his beloved Maryland. Our hearts ache for Patti and his family at this immensely difficult time. May his memory be a blessing.

Our lives were intertwined, starting with our days together at the University of Maryland Law School and then serving together in the Maryland General Assembly. Myrna and I were privileged to have Mike Miller in our lives for all these years.

It will take time for me to process that we have really lost Mike Miller. He was a Maryland institution, as the longest serving Senate president in our state’s history. But even more, he was a cherished friend.
